bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Henry Rose Carter, November 15, 1921

div1.p: Noguchi appreciates Carter's in-depth analysis of his article. He discusses individual sections of article and looks forward to additional comments or suggestions.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Henry Rose Carter, November 15, 1921
div1.opener:
Y. F.
Noguchi
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
November 15, 1921
Dear General Carter:
div1.p:
I am very sorry that my reprints did not reach
you. My secretary sent them to Lima, thinking that you were still
in Peru. She mailed another set to you in Washington as soon as
your letter came.

I was happy to hear from you and appreciate your
letting me see the copy of your painstaking analysis of my article.
I was not satisfied with the article as it appeared. I did not want
to publish it alone, and Lyster was to be joint author in it, but he was
at work in the field much of the time and wrote me on the eve of his
expedition into Mexico in the spring that he thought it better for me to
write a brief summary of the results, which he would follow with detailed
clinical reports by himself and others who actually used the vaccine and
serum in the field. It seemed to be time to publish something of the
results. Guiteras, immediately on return from West Africa in January
of this year, when he could hardly have had time to learn anything of
what had been done in the way of vaccination and treatment, wrote an
article criticising my work and incidentally mentioning that there was
no proof that the serum and vaccine was of any value. Finally, on the
advice of Dr. Flexner, I wrote the brief resumé of the data I had,
purposely leaving details for discussion in a more comprehensive report.

Your comment regarding my view of the incubation
period in yellow fever seems to be based on a misunderstanding. My
statement was as follows: “Since the longest incubation period in
yellow fever in man...is 12 days and the average from 3 to 6 days, the
group of vaccinated individuals...who contracted yellow fever within
from 1 to 10 days after vaccination must be excluded from a considera-
tion of the protective effect of the vaccination”. I did not ascribe
the failure of protection to the length of the incubation period in yellow
fever, but to the fact that immunity produced by vaccination is incom-
plete until about 10 days after vaccination. I mentioned the French
finding of 12 days merely as a possibility, but my stress of course falls on
the average of 3 to 6 days, as anyone must necessarily base his opinion
on the average and not on the extremes. If my English was not clear to
you, my intention was to deal with the average. I quoted the average
without mentioning sources, as the article was of general nature, but
anyone who is interested in yellow fever knows so well your work in the
-2-

accurate determination of the incubation period.

On page 13 I have underscored my discussion as to the use of
other anti-yellow-fever measures than that of vaccination.

Vaccination was in all these instances carried out for the
express purpose of comparison, and conditions were made as nearly similar
as possible for vaccinated and unvaccinated. In Tuxpan, for example,
no particular section of the town was set aside and vaccinated, but those
persons who were living in the neighborhood of yellow fever foci and were
most liable to be exposed to the infection were taken, or those who,
being nonimmune, applied for vaccination because of fear of exposure.
Perhaps I should have made this clear in my article. I just mentioned
that the comparison was made under similar conditions. In Salvador,
also, persons in the infected areas were vaccinated, and this is stated
on page 11. I believe that it is not unusual that certain sections of
a large town are more affected in yellow fever epidemics than others,
according to living conditions and geographic distribution of cases,
but I think this situation was not a factor in Tuxpan.

The clinical data regarding the effect of the anti-icteroides
serum upon the condition of the patients were left out of this summary.
The individual reports, however, refer to abrupt amelioration of symptoms
after serum treatment, and many who have used the serum have stated
enthusiastically that a remarkable improvement in general condition has
followed the injections.

If you have any further comments or suggestions, I should be
very grateful if you will write me again.
With warm regards and best wishes, I am
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, Hideyo Noguchi General H. R. Carter
2121 California St. N.W.
Washington, D.C.
